body: Thanks for your report. It would be great if you reduce your issue to a small reproducible example. Best put this example into a github repository together with instructions how to get to the problem.

> Thanks for your report. It would be great if you reduce your issue to a small reproducible example. Best put this example into a github repository together with instructions how to get to the problem.

I will try to do that, although I am not really sure this will work, since I don't know what actually causes the problem. The line in question works fine on other occasions, so it seems to be a special combination with other things that causes it.

What I can say so far is that the code compiles fine when I downgrade webpack to `4.44.2` (from `5.3.2`) and terser-webpack-plugin to `4.2.2` (from `5.0.3`, since it doesn't support webpack@4 anymore).

This might not help, but I have spent many hours today trying to build a small reproducible sample to post an issue of this exact same bug with the minimizer. Since @raimund-schluessler beat me to it, I'll hijack this issue instead.

For me, it reproduces on this line;

```
import Dropzone from "dropzone"
Dropzone.autoDiscover = false;
```

which gets minimized to 

```
hu._withStripped = (!0)(Nl()).autoDiscover = !1;
```

The offending code is inside a Vue component, all transpiled with Babel and minimized with Terser. It's contained within a pretty large project, and reproduces only when building a production build after upgrading from Webpack 4 to Webpack 5.3.2 and Terser 5.0.3. A development build runs perfectly.

When breaking down my large project into a smaller sample, it does not reproduce and the same line gets translated to:

```
s().autoDiscover=!1
```

which of course works. The **_withStripped** seems to be in @raimund-schluessler code as well, so perhaps this is somehow related to finding the bug.

Could the **_withStripped** part aid somehow in how to build a reproducible sample? What does it mean and is this something that Webpack/Terser exports or is it some other part of the ecosystem?

I managed to create a MWE, you can find it under https://github.com/raimund-schluessler/mwe-webpack-11897.

Just clone the repository, run `npm ci` and `npm run build` afterwards and checkout `js/mwe.js`. I ran it on the bash with `js mwe.js` and got `TypeError: true is not a function`.

Let me know if I can be of any more help.

issue.title: improve handling of ASI in concatenated modules and with imports

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

body: @sokra Unfortunately the issue is not fixed with webpack 5.4.0 although #11904 is included as far as I know. Please checkout the updated MWE under https://github.com/raimund-schluessler/mwe-webpack-11897. Running the compiled javascript still gives `TypeError: true is not a function`. Please let me know if can help debugging this.
@sokra @raimund-schluessler can confirm that my similar issue was resolved with 5.4.0, but adding my code in your MWE did not reproduce so perhaps they have different root cause?

body: Can I somehow test #11920 before the release of 5.4.1?
Yes use the `master` branch of webpack
I can confirm that the issue has been fixed in the MWE as well as in my production build. Thanks a lot!

issue.title: fix: ASI in concatenated module only when necessary

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->
<!-- Explain the **motivation** for making this change. What existing problem does the pull request solve? -->
<!-- Try to link to an open issue for more information. -->

<!-- In addition to that please answer these questions: -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?**

Only add a prefix semicolon in the concatenated module when necessary.

The fixed semicolon was introduced in https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/11897. The strange part is that the test case in that pull request does not work because it requires enabling â `optimization.concatenateModules`. Therefore, I moved the case to the config cases. The test cases will fail when I only remove the semicolon â in `\n;// CONCATENATED MODULE:` without making any other changes, indicating that it is now functioning normally.

Related tracking issue https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/issues/7591#issuecomment-2298602471.
